results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.credit_line_for_label:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric

results.title: Alt-Right Arabesque
results.credit_line:
Baiden Pailthorpe
Single-channel video, 3 mins.
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Single channel video, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Alt-Right Arabesque continues Pailthorpe’s interest in the performing digital body, yet with a new focus on the aesthetics of the resurgent and re-branded fascism (the so-called Alt-right). The sickly-looking protagonist in this work symbolises the infamous 4chan moderator or frequent Reddit user, who spectacularly twirls en arabesque in box-fresh Nike Airmax. A variety of surreal political imagery, visual references and cinematic techniques long associated with fascism and propaganda in the history of cinema are combined in this animation to create a strange and intense response to the overwhelming weirdness of 2016.
[Source: https://sydneycontemporary.com.au/video17/
Last accessed 2/9/2020]

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.
results.title_for_label: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films

results.title: The Muncher for ZX Spectrum 128
results.creator_credit: Rob Howard, Beam Software, Gremlin Graphics Software and Zero Wait
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, badge and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Howard, Beam Software, Gremlin Graphics Software and Zero Wait
